## Reporting Uncertainty

::: {.bitlower .fragment}
$\textit{m} = 1.03 \pm 0.03 \text{ kg (95% confidence)}$
:::

::: {.lower .fragment}
$\textit{u} = 2.36 \pm 0.04 \text{ m/s (95% confidence)}$
:::

::: {.hmmlower .fragment}
$\textit{mu} = 2.43 \pm 0.08 \text{ }\text{ kg}\cdot\text{m/s }\text{ (95% confidence)}$
:::

::: {.lowerstill .fragment}
$\frac{1}{2}\textit{mu}\mathrm{^2} = 2.87 \pm 0.13 \text{J (95% confidence)}$
:::

::: {.lotslower .fragment}
A future video will teach you how to propagate the uncertainty. $\textbf{Remember!}$ A responsible engineer will report uncertainty in the calculated quantity due to the uncertainties present in measured quantities.
:::

## True Mean and Standard Deviation
::: {.fragment}
True value of a measured quantity $\rightarrow$ True Mean or Population Mean
:::

::: {.fragment}
True/Population Mean $\equiv \mu$
:::

::: {.fragment}
Average value from infinite-precision, full population measurement (almost never known) $\rightarrow \mu$ 
:::

::: {.fragment .littlelower}
Distribution of data about the true mean $\rightarrow$ True Standard Deviation or Population Standard Deviation
:::

::: {.fragment .littlelower}
True/Population Standard Deviation $\equiv \sigma$
:::

::: {.fragment .littlelower}
 Standard deviation given true mean and infinite-precision data points (also almost never known) $\rightarrow \sigma$
:::
